path_rules.insight: This page is meant for administrators only, but anyone can access it. You should restrict access and use strong passwords. Allowing everyone to reach this page makes it easy for attackers to try to log in and potentially take control of the website.

Anyone can see this login page, which makes it a target for attackers trying to guess passwords. Use strong passwords, HTTPS to secure connections, and limit how many times someone can try to log in to keep the site safe.

path_rules.message: Backup file or folder is accessible
path_rules.insight: Backups often contain important information like user data or passwords. If they are publicly accessible, anyone can download them. Move backups to a safe location and protect them with strong access rules.

Configuration files can contain important settings and secrets for your website. If anyone can access them, they might learn sensitive information. Restrict access and keep these files safe from public view.
Database files store all your website's data. If they are exposed, attackers could steal or damage your data. Always protect database access with strong passwords and keep it hidden from the public.

A Git repository contains the source code of your website. If it is publicly accessible, attackers could see your code, find mistakes, or steal secrets. Remove it from public directories and restrict access to keep your code safe.

This file often contains sensitive information like passwords and API keys. If anyone can access it, your website and services could be compromised. Move it outside the public web folder and set strict access permissions.
Log files may contain user activity or error messages that reveal sensitive information. Restrict access so only authorized people can see them and avoid storing secrets in logs.
Folders meant for testing or development can contain unfinished features or sensitive data. They should not be accessible to the public and should be disabled or removed in production environments.
The phpinfo page shows detailed server information that can help attackers find weaknesses. Remove this file from public access and only allow trusted internal users if needed.
Debug endpoints show internal details of your website that can be exploited. Turn off debug mode in production and restrict access to trusted users only.
This page shows server activity and configuration details. If public, attackers can use it to plan attacks. Limit access to trusted IPs and require authentication.

path_rules.message: Version control or hidden metadata exposed
path_rules.insight: These hidden files are not meant to be public and may reveal source code or system details. Remove them from the web folder to prevent attackers from learning how your site is built.
This folder allows files to be accessed by anyone. Without proper checks, attackers could upload harmful files. Restrict access and make sure only safe file types are allowed.
This directory appears accessible but is likely meant for public images. Make sure it does not contain sensitive or private files by mistake.
These files may allow attackers to run commands on your server. Remove them immediately and review the server for any signs of compromise.
This file shows which PHP packages your project uses. If public, attackers can see your dependencies and potentially find vulnerabilities. Move it out of public directories and restrict access.
This file locks specific versions of your PHP packages. Exposing it can help attackers find exact library versions to target. Keep it outside the web root and limit access.
This file lists JavaScript project dependencies. Public access can reveal your libraries and versions, helping attackers find weaknesses. Move it out of the web root and restrict access.
This file locks exact versions of JavaScript dependencies. Exposing it allows attackers to know the exact versions used, which could be exploited. Keep it secure and away from public access.

Like package-lock.json, this file locks your JavaScript dependencies. Public exposure can help attackers identify vulnerabilities in specific versions. Restrict access and move it out of public directories.

This folder contains all your installed JavaScript packages. If accessible publicly, attackers can see your full code dependencies and possibly exploit known issues. Remove it from public directories.
APIs may contain sensitive operations. If exposed without authentication, attackers could misuse them. Restrict access and enforce proper authentication for all endpoints.
This documentation shows how your API works and can help attackers understand your system. Restrict access and require authentication to keep it private.
The schema reveals details about your API endpoints, parameters, and responses. If public, attackers can plan attacks more easily. Limit access and require authentication.
Backup files often contain sensitive data like user information and passwords. If accessible publicly, anyone can download it. Move backups out of the web root and restrict access.
Like other backup files, this archive may contain critical information. Keep it secure outside public directories and enforce strict access controls.
Database dumps contain all your website’s data. Public access could let attackers steal or manipulate information. Remove it from public directories and restrict access.
Configuration files can include passwords and settings. Public exposure makes it easy for attackers to exploit your site. Move it out of the web root and set proper file permissions.
Settings files may contain sensitive configurations. Keep them out of public access and enforce strict access control.
This file contains database credentials and connection details. Public access can allow attackers to access your database. Move it out of the web root and enforce authentication.
This directory may contain files for security and verification purposes. Limit access where possible to avoid exposing sensitive information.
VSCode folders can contain project-specific settings or secrets. Keep them out of public directories to prevent attackers from learning about your development environment.
IDE folders like .idea may reveal project configurations or sensitive info. Remove them from web-accessible paths and restrict access.
Sitemaps help search engines, but they can also reveal website structure. Verify it does not expose sensitive paths or areas meant to be private.
This file guides search engines but may list directories you want hidden. Review its contents and avoid exposing sensitive endpoints.
Dockerfiles may contain environment setups and credentials. If public, attackers can see how your environment is configured. Move it out of web root and restrict access.
This file contains service definitions and possibly environment variables. Public access can reveal sensitive info about your system setup. Move it out of public directories and restrict access.
Secret JSON files may include API keys or passwords. Anyone accessing them can compromise your system. Remove them from the web root and enforce strict access control.
Key files contain private credentials used for authentication or encryption. Public exposure can lead to full system compromise. Secure them and remove from public directories.
Adminer allows database management. If publicly accessible, attackers can try to access your databases. Restrict access and enforce strong authentication.
phpMyAdmin is a database management tool. Public access can let attackers attempt login attacks or exploit vulnerabilities. Restrict access, enforce authentication, and keep it updated.
Test files are meant for development and may contain code for debugging. Exposing them in production can reveal system behavior. Remove or restrict access.
Info scripts show server and PHP configuration details. Public access can help attackers find weaknesses. Remove the file or restrict access to trusted internal users only.
